node.text:
Since launching operation Sola Stella in 2017, 15 vessels have been arrested the last of which were in 2019, meaning that no arrests have been made there since. 

"This does not mean that we are no longer being effective - it means that we are so effective that no one is committing crimes related to illegal fishing within Liberian waters." - Captain Mar Casariego

Support our fight to combat IUU fishing in Liberia and around the world through the link in our bio!

node.title: How Illegal Fishing in Liberia Ended

node.text:
⚓ Sea Shepherd's volunteer deckhands are essential members of our crew. They're responsible for everything from launching the small boats for an inspection and hauling in illegal fishing nets to cleaning the hull and making all kinds of repairs to make sure the ship stays in top shape. Although many of our deckhands have little or no prior experience at sea, our veteran crew carefully trains them up to ensure everything runs smoothly and safely during our campaigns. 

"Beyond serving the crew and the ship, being a deckhand is getting your hands dirty to save the ocean."

Are you up for the challenge? ✊ Learn more about how you can volunteer for Sea Shepherd's fleet through the link in our bio! 

#crewlife #volunteer #ShipLife #HumansAtSea #Sailor #SeaShepherd #Crew #LifeAtSea #MarineConservation #ForTheOcean #SaveTheOcean #SSCS

node.text:
WARNING: EXTREMELY GRAPHIC AND DISTURBING FOOTAGE

On June 27th, 2021, Sea Shepherd crew witnessed for 175 pilot whales in the Faroe Islands whose lives were mercilessly taken from them in the name of 'tradition'. The dead included juveniles and pregnant females, whose almost fully formed fetuses were discarded as trash 💔

The crew's cameras captured all kinds of atrocities and disrespect for life, including a boat deliberately ramming directly into a small group of whales that were resisting being driven onto the killing beach, then maneuvering with the boat's propeller right over the top of the whales.

What is shown in this video is but a glimpse.

Our crew is on the islands to be the voice of the whales. They mean no harm, yet they are threatened and harassed by locals who don't want their "proud" tradition documented and exposed to the world.

Please do show your support to the whales and our crew by liking and commenting below - this helps us get the message out.

#FaroeIslands #f #visitfaroeislands #FaroeIsland #faroe #roamthefaroeislands #faroeislandsnature #faroese #guidetofaroeislands #SeaShepherd #Grind #Grindadrap #føroyar #foroyar #føroya #SaveTheOcean #Wildlife #Pilotwhales #Whales #Dolphins #ForTheOcean #SSCS

node.text:
The oceans are the source of all life. They inspire us, they delight us, and they provide 70% of the oxygen we breathe. They are also home to a myriad of species, from the tiniest of turtle hatchlings to the most majestic of whales. These are our clients, and the reason that Sea Shepherd continues to fight. 🌊💙

So say it with us! ✊ Every day is...

node.text:
Presenting the latest addition to the Sea Shepherd fleet; The Sea Eagle!

The ship was purchased with funding from Allianz SE, Allianz Technology, and Allianz Italy as part of Sea Shepherd’s new two-year partnership with Allianz to address the issue of plastic marine debris polluting the ocean. 🌊

The Sea Eagle is a 40-meter former French pilot boat equipped to accommodate 19 crew and carry two small boats. Having been built for the Atlantic Ocean, the ship is capable of navigating the roughest seas. The Sea Shepherd crew worked tirelessly to ensure a smooth transit from Thyborøn, Denmark to Syracuse, Italy, where it’s now preparing for upcoming campaigns in the Mediterranean Sea. 

LEARN more: https://bit.ly/3vmbnFt 👈

node.title: A New Ship! The Sea Eagle Joins Sea Shepherd’s Fleet

node.text:
The ocean is home to millions of incredible marine animals - from tiny phytoplankton to the colossal blue whale. 

But today, the ocean is threatened by destructive fishing practices that are wiping out entire species, destroying ecosystems and dumping millions
of tons of deadly plastic into the seas. Sea Shepherd has been fighting on the frontline for over 40 years and you can join our movement. 

Now is the time to act because if the ocean dies, we die.

node.text:
Six years ago today, the rogue poaching vessel Thunder was scuttled by its own crew after a 110-day high-seas chase by Sea Shepherd as part of Operation Icefish. 

At the start of Operation Icefish in 2014, Sea Shepherd set out to locate and shut down illegal, unreported and unregulated fishing in Antarctica. Infamously named the "Bandit 6", the targets were six illegal poaching vessels known to Interpol and CCAMLR, who had previously managed to evade any law enforcement. Over two campaigns that spanned from 2014 to 2016, Sea Shepherd set the world record for the longest high-seas pursuit of a poaching vessel, removed 72 kilometers of illegal gillnets from the ocean, and successfully shut down all of the Bandit 6 vessels. 

#OpIcefish #PoachersBeware #ChasingTheThunder

node.title: Six Years Ago Today: A Poaching Vessel Goes Down

node.text:
The ocean is under heavy assault from all sides and is urgently calling for backup. Rampant legal and illegal over-fishing, the suffocating mass of plastics, and ocean acidification has a stranglehold on the life support of our planet; the life support that we all depend on to survive. 

Take action now... Before it is too late.

SeaShepherdGlobal.org

Thanks to explosive egg films and television for the animation.

node.title: If the Ocean Dies, We Die.

node.text:
While standing back and observing fishing operations, our crew in the Bay of Biscay on Operation Dolphin Bycatch frequently gets showered with anything from small projectiles from a slingshots to verbal abuse. 

Experience what it takes to expose the massacre of the dolphins 👇

node.text:
Have a listen to the voice of our volunteers, their experiences and what motivates them to dedicate so much of their lives to protecting the ocean.

Support the crew's efforts by purchasing our merch, becoming a part of the movement, and reminding everyone that the ocean still needs our help. 🌏

SeaShepherdStore.com 👈

node.text:
With your support, we have just expanded our international marine conservation efforts, launching a critical new collaboration with Conflict Islands Conservation Initiative (CICI) and Animal Assist to protect endangered turtles from poaching in the Conflict Islands in Papua New Guinea.

This atoll is known as one of Sylvia Earle’s Hope Spots and is an important nesting site for hawksbill and green sea turtles. 🐢

“Without the support in these difficult times from organisations such as Sea Shepherd and Animal Assist, we would not be able to continue our critical work to protect wildlife and conserve our wild places” - CICI’s Operations Manager Hayley Versace. 

Read more: http://bit.ly/3621cM5

node.title: Defending Turtles in Papua New Guinea

node.text:
Every year, hundreds of people get to call a ship in our fleet their temporary home. These people can be teachers, factory operators, nurses, lawyers, bakers, drivers and everything in between. They come from countries all over the world and are of pretty much all ages. In Sea Shepherd, our diversity is our strength, and while certain maritime roles are needed, such as marine engineers and navigational officers, we also need pretty much any other skill to be self-sufficient at sea. 

So what are you waiting for? If you think that you need have all the licenses and qualifications to get on board, think again. All we ask is that you have a passion for the ocean and are willing to learn from our experienced crew. Consider applying today through the link in our bio!

Have you applied yet? Why/why not?

📸 Glenn Lockitch / Sea Shepherd

#Crew #Volunteering #ForTheOcean #ShipLife #LifeAtSea #HumansAtSea #SeaShepherd #SSCS #ForTheOcean #MarineConservation #SaveTheOcean #Activism

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Sea Shepherd in Gabon, Africa. May be an image of 1 person and body of water.

node.text:
Shrimp trawler busted in Gabon!

A few days ago, the Renovation 2, a shrimp trawler, was busted red-handed using undersized fishing gear while fishing for shrimp in Gabonese waters, which prevented juvenile fish from escaping capture and resulted in an incredibly large amount of bycatch thrown back into the sea, dead.

While shrimp trawlers are already incredibly destructive, with an average of six kilos of bycatch for each one kilo of shrimp caught, the Renovation 2 was much much worse with an estimation of about 500 kilos of bycatch to a single kilo of shrimp. 

The Gabonese Minister of fisheries, Minister Maganga-Moussavou, accompanied the boarding team, saying “These wasteful practices cannot be tolerated in Gabon. I have commissioned an official inquiry into the shrimp fishery and pending the outcome of the investigation, I am prepared to suspend the fishing season until a solution can be found to the bycatch problem”.

*In the photo is Gabonese Fisheries Minister, Maganga-Moussavou in front of the detained vessel.

Check out the full story through the link in our bio!

📸 Youen Kerdavid / Sea Shepherd

#PoachersBeware #Shrimp #Shrimptrawl #IUUFishing #Illegalfishing #Gabon #Africa #SeaShepherd #OpAlbacore #SSCS #MarineConservation #SaveTheOcean #ForTheOcean

node.text:
It's the ocean's very own magic, the aurora, but in the sea, and is absolutely sure to bring the crew on deck. 

Bioluminescence stems from chemical reactions in small marine species and organisms when they or the water they are in gets disturbed, like when they are in a wave that breaks on a beach or when a ship passes by 

Have you ever seen bioluminescence in person? If so, where? 

📸 Guillermo Reverter Cid / Sea Shepherd

#Bioluminescence #Lights #Light #Ocean #Wildlife #ForTheOcean #SeaShepherd #SaveTheOcean

node.text:
Earlier this month, while on patrol for illegal fishing in Gabonese waters, the crew of the Bob Barker spotted a massive European tuna fishing vessel with two endangered Humpback Whales caught in its net.

Despite being required by law to stop fishing to immediately free the whales, the ship continually tightened its nets to get to the tuna caught in the same net.

This is not the first time Sea Shepherd has seen whales caught in the nets of fishing vessels, and it is certainly far from the first time it has ever happened as 300,000 whales and dolphins are estimated to be killed every year by industrial fishing and especially IUU fishing.

After a long struggle, the whales were eventually freed from the net and able to swim away. Hearing of the incident, Gabonese Minister of Fisheries, Honorable Biendi Maganga-Moussavou, took immediate action by sanctioning the vessel and committed to personally joining the next fisheries patrol in Gabonese waters.

READ the full story and watch the video of the harrowing ordeal through the link in our bio. (WARNING, it can be a hard watch)

Before the Gabonese law banned the practice in Gabonese waters, it was common for tuna-fishing vessels to intentionally set their nets around whales and whale sharks. Do you know why?

📸 Youenn Kerdavid / Salomé Tordjman / Richard Murphy / Sea Shepherd

#Whales #Bycatch #endangered #endangeredspecies #Humpback #Nets #Fishing #Wildlife #ExtinctionIsForever #Overfishing #Industrialfishing #Fishing #SeaShepherd #ForTheOcean #MarineConservation #SaveTheOcean #SSCS #Whale #Gabon #Africa

Since launching operation Sola Stella in 2017, 15 vessels have been arrested the last of which were in 2019, meaning that no arrests have been made there since. 

"This does not mean that we are no longer being effective - it means that we are so effective that no one is committing crimes related to illegal fishing within Liberian waters." - Captain Mar Casariego

Support our fight to combat IUU fishing in Liberia and around the world through the link in our bio!

node.text:
Saving the ocean doesn't necessarily require taking time away from family and work and staying on a ship for months on end. You can make a difference, simply by changing you habits at home! One of those habits, could perhaps be your diet

How are diets connected to the health of the ocean? Well, the animal agriculture industry has historically been linked to many massive ocean dead-zones around the world, killing the ocean with the run-off pollution from large-scale factory farming. Wild fish are being used to feed domesticated farm animals, making the meat industry the biggest consumer of ocean wildlife on the planet with cows, chickens, and pigs now being the world's largest aquatic predator. Fish farming, seen by some as a solution to overfishing, just leads to even more overfishing as the farmed fish have to eat too. And gas pollution, especially from cattle farms, is driving up ocean acidity, rendering the shelled marine animals defenseless and corals bleached and dead. - In short, animal agriculture is killing the ocean.

This is exactly why our ships are fully vegan. Our crews thrive on a nutritious and, quite frankly delicious, plant-based diet. Our cooks work incredibly hard to make three meals a day to keep the ship's crew running, a job which some call the hardest on board.

All that being said, our crewmembers consist of both vegan and non-vegan people, everyone is welcome, but everyone eats vegan when onboard in Neptunes Navy.

What's a great plant-based dish for a new vegan? 

📷 Tara Lambourne / Sea Shepherd

Please keep the discussion civil in the comments.

#Vegansofig #Veganfood #Plantbased #Vegan #Veganism #Green #ForTheOcean #SaveTheOcean #SeaShepherd #MarineConservation #VeganForTheOcean #Veggie #Veganlife
